Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Campaigning for Better Black Hole Mass Relations
Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to understand the physical relationship between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies, it is essential to determine the mass of the black hole itself. Unfortunately we are limited to directly measuring black hole masses in nearby galaxies. In order to fully understand the energetic impact of black holes at cosmological distances, we must instead use secondary indicators to estimate their masses. These so-called scaling relationships are fundamental to our knowledge of galaxies and black holes at high redshifts, but they remain poorly determined. The PI will perform a multiwavelength observational program that is targeted at removing many known sources of uncertainty and scatter among a sample of Active Galactic Nuclei with direct black hole mass measurements. The PI will (1) carry out a new reverberation mapping survey to measure black hole masses in 20 galaxies; (2) use integral field unit observations of the nuclear region to measure stellar dynamics; and (3) derive distances to the host galaxies using 21 cm spectroscopy.

This program will solidify the scaling relationships that are heavily used by the community for estimating black hole masses at cosmological distances and will pave the way for a significant leap forward in our understanding of galaxies and black holes throughout cosmic history. The PI will also partner with the Girl Scouts of Greater Atlanta to create and present astronomy workshops for Girl Scouts in grades 4-5 and high school. The PI's work will reach thousands of young girls, and she will encourage their interest in science and observations of the natural world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Black holes are known to lurk in the centers of galaxies. While they are often depicted as  mysterious objects, black holes are very simple because they can be fully described with only three quantities.  One of these quantities is mass, and it is deduced from the gravitational force of the black hole.

There are only a few different ways that the mass of a black hole can be measured, and because of the requirements of each technique, a single black hole can generally only have its mass measured using one method.  We have focused on building up a sample of black holes that may have their masses compared through two of the most widely used mass techniques, to carefully test for the first time whether both techniques give the same answers for the same black holes.  Through this project, we have measured new black hole masses and succeeded in tripling the size of the sample.  We have also identified several other candidates that may be added to the sample after more examination.  One of these candidates has one of the smallest black hole masses yet measured for a galaxy, making it an interesting target for studies that seek to understand where black holes in galaxy centers come from.

We have also observed many galaxies that have known black hole masses in visible, near-infrared, and radio light and using several different observational techniques.  This work represents hundreds of hours of telescope time.  The data that we have collected have allowed us to carefully analyze several relationships between black hole mass and galaxy properties, some for the first time and others with significant improvements.  These so-called scaling relationships are often compared with computer models of galaxy growth, and they are widely used to predict large numbers of black hole masses for other investigations.  Our work has increased the variety of scaling relationships available to the community, improved their quality, and has demonstrated that some commonly-held assumptions are wrong and should no longer be used. 

The intellectual merits of this project allow for a better understanding of how galaxies and black holes grow and evolve over time, ultimately leading to a better understanding of how our universe came to be the way that it is and how we came to be here observing it.

The broader impacts of the project focused on daytime events for Junior Girl Scouts.  These events focused on astronomy that you can do during the day - observing our very own star, the Sun.  Each event included interactive discussions about the Sun and its effects on Earth, as well as hands-on activities allowing each girl to build her own scientific instruments from household supplies and take them home for ongoing investigation.  The Girl Scouts is a unique organization that focuses on building girls of ?courage, confidence, and character?, and our purpose in sharing the excitement of science and providing real-life examples of women scientists was to encourage each participant to seriously consider a future in STEM.

Finally, throughout the duration of the project we have sought ways to share the excitement of science with the greater Atlanta community.  This has involved numerous public engagement activities in partnership with the annual Atlanta Science Festival, the Atlanta Science Tavern, the Atlanta Astronomy Club, the Atlanta chapter of 500 Women Scientists, and other organizations.  Events have included panel discussions, documentary screenings, public lectures, Q&A events, school visits, radio interviews, and more, all undertaken in the spirit of sharing our knowledge of the universe as widely and accessibly as possible.
